header.title: THE DEVIL IN BRITAIN AND AMERICA

central_thesis: John Ashton's 'The Devil in Britain and America' meticulously documents the historical evolution of beliefs concerning the Devil and witchcraft across British and American societies. Through a comprehensive compilation of historical accounts, ballads, and legal records from ancient times to the late 19th century, the work illustrates the changing perceptions of demonic influence, the accused practices of witches, and the societal impact of these esoteric fears. The central premise is a historical survey of the 'operative' aspects of magic and demonology as understood and reported during various periods, rather than a practical guide to such practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER I. Universal Belief in the Personality of the Devil, as portrayed by the British Artist—Arguments in Favour of his Personality—Ballad 'Terrible and Seasonable Warning to Young Men.'
structure_content.summary: This chapter establishes the pervasive historical belief in an evil entity (the Devil) across various cultures, from ancient Typho and Beelzebub to Nordic Loki. It traces the evolving depiction of the Devil from an abstract evil to a tangible, often monstrous, figure with chimerical features. The chapter introduces the idea of the Devil's 'democratic' interactions with humans to secure souls, exemplified by a ballad where a poor Essex man is deceived by a tall man in black.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER II. 'Strange and True News from Westmoreland'—'The Politic Wife'—'How the Devill, though subtle, was guld by a Scold'—'The Devil's Oak'—Raising the Devil—Arguments in Favour of Devils—The Number of Devils.
structure_content.summary: Chapter II continues the discussion of the Devil's manifestations in human or animal form, showcasing instances where human cleverness (e.g., 'The Politic Wife') outwitted the demonic entity. It delves into the historical context of conjuring the Devil and details the extensive cataloging of various demonic entities and their legions, such as those found in Reginald Scot's work, providing a technical overview of perceived demonic hierarchy and power.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER III. 'The Just Devil of Woodstock'—Metrical Version—Presumed Genuine History of 'The Just Devil of Woodstock.'
structure_content.summary: This chapter meticulously recounts the famous poltergeist activity known as the 'Devil of Woodstock' (1649). It describes a series of disturbances, including nocturnal noises, object manipulation (chairs, stools, pewter dishes, stones being thrown), beds shaking violently, and loud 'trotting' sounds. The historical account attributes these phenomena to a deliberate prank orchestrated by a servant, Joe Collins, utilizing hidden mechanisms and chemical compounds.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV. 'The Daemon of Tedworth.'
structure_content.summary: The 'Daemon of Tedworth' case (1661) is detailed, focusing on disturbances in Mr. Mompesson's house, initiated by a former drummer. The manifestations included incessant drum beating, knocking on doors and walls, visible lights, moving objects, and physical assaults. The 'daemon' specifically targeted children and was strongly linked to the drummer, who was later prosecuted for forgery, providing a detailed case study of alleged instrumental magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER V. 'The Daemon of Burton'—'Strange and Wonderful News from Yowel, in Surrey'—'The Story of Mrs. Jermin—A Case at Welton'—'The Relation of James Sherring.'
structure_content.summary: This chapter presents a series of historical accounts detailing localized demonic or witchcraft-induced disturbances. Cases like the 'Daemon of Burton' involved objects being moved, grain mingled, food spoiled, and crops disrupted. The Yowel case describes a maid suffering from internal pins and thorns, attributed to a local witch. Further narratives include poltergeist phenomena affecting a minister and a girl who purportedly vomited stones and coals.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VI. A Demon in Gilbert Campbell's Family—Case of Sir William York—Case of Ian Smagge—Disturbances at Stockwell.
structure_content.summary: Chapter VI continues with further accounts of domestic disturbances attributed to malevolent entities. The Gilbert Campbell family in Scotland experienced destruction of weaving tools, stone-throwing, and theft of clothing, linked to a beggar. Sir William York's house endured lifted latches and moving furniture. The Ian Smagge case documents poltergeist activity with strange noises and thrown glass. The Stockwell disturbances (1772) detail objects breaking and flying, prominently featuring a maid as the focal point.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VII. Possession by, and casting out, Devils—The Church and Exorcisms—Earlier Exorcists—'The Strange and Grievous Vexation by the Devil of 7 Persons in Lancashire.'
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the New Testament's portrayal of demonic possession and the early Christian Church's methods of exorcism, emphasizing the use of holy water and the cross. It details the 'Strange and Grievous Vexation' of seven persons in Lancashire (1594), attributing their fits, speaking foreign languages, and physical torments to the conjurer Edmund Hartlay, providing examples of early modern exorcistic beliefs.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VIII. James I. on Possession—The Vexation of Alexander Nyndge—'Wonderful News from Buckinghamshire'—Sale of a Devil.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses King James I.'s theories on demonology, particularly criteria for diagnosing possession, such as unnatural strength and xenoglossia. It elaborates on the 'Vexation of Alexander Nyndge' (1615), where the tormented individual displayed severe physical contortions and vocal alterations. A notable anecdote involves the 'sale' of a devil in a specific legalistic transaction, highlighting the period's understanding of demonic contracts.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. The Witch of Endor—The 'Mulier Malefica' of Berkeley—Northern Witches.
structure_content.summary: Chapter IX examines the figure of the witch, beginning with the biblical Witch of Endor. It then explores the 'Old Woman of Berkeley' and the belief in shapeshifting. A significant portion is dedicated to the 'Northern Witches' (Laplanders, Finlanders), detailing their reputed powers such as weather manipulation (raising storms, selling winds), and the use of effigies. It also describes the various tools and ingredients (e.g., 'witchery meat') used in their magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER X. The Legal Witch—James I. on Witches—Reginald Scot on Witches—Addison on Witches.
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines the legal concept of a witch according to English statutes (e.g., James I., 1604), outlining specific acts of invocation, covenant, and maleficium. It contrasts the legal view with Reginald Scot's skeptical perspective, which often attributed 'witchcraft' to natural phenomena and human malevolence. The chapter also introduces Addison's later, more nuanced view, acknowledging the existence of spirits but questioning the specifics of witchcraft accusations.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI. How a Witch was made—Her Compact with the Devil—Hell Broth—Homage and Feasting—The Witches' Sabbat.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XI provides a detailed account of the perceived process of becoming a witch, focusing on the Devil's pact. This involves renouncing Christian faith, offering blood, and receiving familiar spirits or arcane knowledge. It graphically describes the preparation of 'hell broth' (flying ointments) and the methods of aerial travel (broomsticks, transformed animals) to the Witches' Sabbat. The Sabbat rituals are depicted, including adoration of Satan, ecstatic dances, and banquets featuring specific, unsalted foods.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XII. Familiar Spirits—Matthew Hopkins, the 'Witch-finder'—Prince Rupert's dog Boy—Unguents used for transporting Witches from Place to Place—Their Festivities at the Sabbat.
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the role of familiar spirits (Imps) in witchcraft, often appearing as animals like cats or dogs, acting as assistants to witches. It highlights the influence of Matthew Hopkins, the 'Witch-finder,' and his methods, particularly the identification of 'Devil's marks' or 'teats' where familiars were believed to suckle. The chapter also reiterates the use of magical unguents for astral or physical travel to Sabbats, where witches engaged in various 'festivities' with their demonic patrons.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIII. Waxen Figures—Witches change into Animals—Witch Marks—Testimony against Witches—Tests for, and Examination of, Witches.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XIII focuses on the practical techniques attributed to witches, such as the creation of waxen images for sympathetic magic (causing illness or death by manipulation of the effigy). It explores the belief in lycanthropy or shapeshifting into animals. The chapter heavily details the methods of identifying witches, including the discovery of 'Devil's marks' and the various forms of 'tests' and examinations used during trials, highlighting the coercive nature of obtaining confessions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIV. Legislation against Witches—Punishment—Last Executions for Witchcraft—Inability to weep and sink—Modern Cases of Witchcraft.
structure_content.summary: This chapter traces the legal history of witchcraft in England, from the establishment of capital crimes to its eventual decriminalization. It discusses the severe punishments, including burning, and the 'ordeals' used to determine guilt or innocence, such as the inability to weep or the water trial (swimming as a witch). The chapter also presents later, 19th-century accounts that illustrate a lingering belief in minor witchcraft, demonstrating its persistence in folklore.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV. Commencement of Witchcraft in England—Dame Eleanor Cobham—Jane Shore—Lord Huntingford—Cases from the Calendars of State Papers—Earliest Printed Case, that of John Walsh—Elizabeth Stile—Three Witches tried at Chelmsford—Witches of St. Osyth—Witches of Warboys—Witches of Northamptonshire.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XV explores early English witchcraft cases, often with political undertones, such as Dame Eleanor Cobham's use of wax effigies. It presents various 16th-century trials, including John Walsh's confession of trafficked 'Feries' and the Chelmsford witches' accounts of familiar spirits and maleficium. These cases illustrate the developing legal and popular understanding of witchcraft during a formative period in England.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVI. The Lancashire Witches—Janet Preston—Margaret and Philip Flower—Anne Baker, Joane Willimot, and Ellen Greene—Elizabeth Sawyer—Mary Smith—Joan Williford, Joan Cariden, and Jane Hott.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides detailed accounts from prominent English witch trials, such as those of the Lancashire Witches (1612). It compiles confessions describing familiar spirits in various animal forms (foals, spaniels, rabbits) that assist in causing sickness, death, and property damage. Specific attention is given to the 'sucking' of familiars from witches' bodies and the details of their demonic pacts, offering insight into the perceived operative mechanics of their magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVII. Confessions of Witches executed in Essex—The Witches of Huntingdon—'Wonderful News from the North'—Trial of Six Witches at Maidstone—Trial of Four Witches at Worcester—A Lancashire Witch tried at Worcester—A Tewkesbury Witch.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XVII focuses on the confessions and trials of witches in Essex and Huntingdon (1645-1646), often under the influence of the 'Witch-finder' Matthew Hopkins. The accounts describe familiars with distinct names and their roles in causing specific harms. Further cases from Worcester (1647) and Tewkesbury (1649) detail accusations of suckling pigs as polecats and inflicting illnesses, providing a vivid picture of the types of accusations and confessions prevalent during intense witch-hunts.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVIII. A Case of Vomiting Stones, etc., at Evesham—Anne Bodenham—Julian Cox—Elizabeth Styles—Rose Cullender and Amy Duny.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines cases involving unusual physical phenomena and diverse forms of alleged witchcraft. The Evesham case (1652) describes a girl expelling stones, pins, and brass, attributed to Catherine Huxley. Anne Bodenham (1653) was a 'cunning woman' accused of conjuring devils and poisoning. Julian Cox (1663) was tried for shapeshifting into a hare. Elizabeth Styles (1664) confessed to a pact with the Devil in human and animal forms. Rose Cullender and Amy Duny (1664) faced accusations of bewitching children to vomit pins.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIX. The Case of Mary Hill of Beckington—The Confession of Alice Huson—Florence Newton of Youghal—Temperance Lloyd (or Floyd), Mary Trembles, and Susannah Edwards.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XIX delves into specific confessions and trials, providing detailed accounts of alleged magical practices. Mary Hill (1691) was accused of causing pin-vomiting. Alice Huson (1664) confessed to a pact with a 'Black Man on a Horse.' Florence Newton (1661) was an Irish witch accused of stone-throwing and inducing illness. The Exeter witches (1682)—Temperance Lloyd, Mary Trembles, and Susannah Edwards—confessed to tormenting victims, entering pacts with the Devil in various forms (black man, lion), and ritualistic blood-sucking.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XX. Elizabeth Horner—Pardons for Witchcraft—A Witch taken in London—Sarah Mordike—An Impostor convicted—Case of Jane Wenham—The Last Witch hanged in England.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on later witchcraft cases, reflecting the decline of severe prosecutions. Elizabeth Horner (1696) was acquitted despite accusations of her children vomiting pins. The chapter highlights instances of pardons for witchcraft and the case of Sarah Mordike (1701), accused of bewitching Richard Hathaway, who was subsequently declared an impostor. The narrative culminates with the trial of Jane Wenham (1712) in Hertfordshire, one of the last prominent witchcraft trials in England, though resulting in a reprieve.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXI. Scotch Witches—Bessie Dunlop—Alesoun Peirson—Dr. John Fian—The Devil a Preacher—Examination of Agnes Sampson—Confession of Issobel Gowdie.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XXI extensively covers Scottish witchcraft, characterized by its brutal trials and widespread belief. Bessie Dunlop (1576) consulted a deceased 'Thome Reid' for healing and lost goods. Alesoun Peirson (1588) claimed instruction from a deceased cousin. Dr. John Fian (1590) was accused of being the Devil's 'register' and officiating at Sabbats. Agnes Sampson (1591) confessed to sailing in sieves and dancing at Sabbats to harm the King. Issobell Gowdie (1662) provided highly detailed confessions of pacts, shapeshifting, familiar spirits, and specific malefic practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXII. Early Witchcraft in Scotland—Lady Glamys—Bessie Dunlop—Lady Foulis—Numerous Cases.
structure_content.summary: This chapter further explores early Scottish witchcraft, with a focus on notable individuals and their politically charged accusations. The case of Lady Glamys (1532, 1537) is presented, involving accusations of poisoning and witchcraft, often used as instruments of political persecution. The chapter underscores the severity of the legal responses and the societal context of these early modern magical accusations in Scotland.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIII. Witchcraft in America—In Illinois : Moreau and Emmanuel—In Virginia : Case of Grace Sherwood—In Pennsylvania : Two Swedish Women—In South Carolina—In Connecticut : Many Cases—In Massachusetts: Margaret Jones; Mary Parsons; Ann Hibbins; Other Cases.
structure_content.summary: Chapter XXIII shifts to American witchcraft, tracing its roots from British beliefs. It details cases from various colonies: Illinois (1790) with Moreau and Emmanuel accused of necromancy; Virginia (1706) with Grace Sherwood undergoing the water trial; Pennsylvania's two Swedish women; and numerous cases in Connecticut (1646-1697). The chapter culminates in Massachusetts, presenting the earliest execution of Margaret Jones (1648) and other cases like Mary Parsons and Ann Hibbins.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIV. Cotton and Increase Mather—The Case of Goodwin's Daughter—That of Mr. Philip Smith—The Story of the Salem Witchcrafts—List of Victims—Release of Suspects—Reversal of Attainder, and Compensation.
structure_content.summary: This final chapter focuses on the Salem Witchcraft Trials (1692) and the significant influence of Cotton and Increase Mather. It details 'The Case of Goodwin's Daughter,' describing children's violent spasms, animalistic behaviors, and invisible torments attributed to Goody Glover. The chapter discusses the legal proceedings, spectral evidence, and lists numerous victims, including prominent figures like Sarah Good, Martha Corey, and Ann Hibbins, concluding with the eventual release of suspects, reversal of attainder, and compensation to victims' families.

key_concepts.definition: The historical conception of the Devil evolving from an abstract evil force to a concrete, anthropomorphic, or zoomorphic entity (e.g., black man, he-goat, dog, cat, toad, hare, fowl, snake, lion). Operatively, he is portrayed as a tempter, a contract-maker, a granter of power, and an active participant in Sabbats and various forms of maleficium.

A formal or informal agreement between a human (witch) and the Devil, often involving the renunciation of Christian faith, the offering of blood or a bodily mark, and the reception of familiar spirits, magical knowledge, or power to cause harm (maleficium).

Demonic entities, typically appearing in animal forms (e.g., cats, dogs, foals, rabbits, polcats), bestowed upon witches by the Devil. They are believed to suckle from specific 'Devil's marks' on the witch's body and assist in performing acts of witchcraft, such as causing illness, death, or material damage.

Nocturnal assemblies of witches and devils, often held on Fridays or specific dates, described as a parody of religious services. Rituals include adoration of Satan (who may appear as a black man or he-goat), circular dances performed back-to-back, banquets with unusual, unsalted foods (sometimes perceived as human flesh), and reporting of malicious deeds performed on Satan's behalf.

Magical salves, reputedly concocted from gruesome ingredients like children's fat and various herbs. These ointments were believed to be rubbed on the body or on objects (like broomsticks or transformed animals) to enable aerial travel to Sabbats or other locations for magical operations.

A practice involving the creation of wax or clay figures representing individuals. These effigies were then ritually manipulated (e.g., roasted, pricked with pins or thorns, burned) to inflict corresponding pain, illness, or death upon the targeted person.

Insensible spots (e.g., blue-spots, red-spots, areas of hollowed flesh) or 'teats' found on a witch's body, believed to be points where familiar spirits suckled. These marks were considered tangible evidence of a pact with the Devil during witch trials.

Superstitious tests used during witch trials to determine guilt or innocence. Examples include the 'water trial' (where floating indicated guilt, sinking innocence) and the 'weighing of a witch' against a church Bible (being lighter than the Bible often implied guilt).

The state of being controlled or inhabited by a demonic entity, manifesting through physical contortions, speaking in unknown languages (xenoglossia), unnatural strength, and an aversion to holy objects or names. Exorcism was the counter-practice to expel these entities.

Magical practices involving the invocation or communication with spirits (including the Devil) for various purposes, such as gaining hidden knowledge (finding treasure), foretelling the future, or commanding spirits to perform malefic acts.

practical_system.description: This book does not provide a practical system for magical operation; rather, it is a historical survey documenting beliefs about occult practices and the accusations levied against alleged practitioners in Britain and America. The 'operative' aspects discussed are derived from historical records of confessed or attributed magical acts, illustrating the perceived mechanics of witchcraft and demonology during specific eras. It details what people *believed* witches and demonologists *did*, not how to replicate those actions.
tools: Familiar Spirits (Imps): Described as animalistic entities (cats, dogs, foals, rabbits, toads, flies) given to witches by the Devil. They were believed to suckle blood from 'Devil's marks' and act as agents for maleficium.

Ointments for Flight: Reputedly made from human fat (often from unbaptized children) mixed with various herbs, these unguents were believed to enable witches to fly to Sabbats on broomsticks or transformed animals.
Broomsticks/Dungforks: Used as 'vehicles' for aerial travel to Sabbats after applying magical ointments.
Wax/Clay Effigies: Small figures used in sympathetic magic to represent victims, manipulated with pins or heat to cause harm.
Pins/Thorns: Small sharp objects used to prick effigies or, in some accounts of possession, spontaneously appear in the victim's body.
Devil's Writing: A unique, undecipherable script presented as an actual specimen of the Devil's own calligraphy, indicating a belief in tangible demonic communication (frontispiece).
Magic Circles: Mentioned in conjuration rituals as protective or operational spaces, often drawn on the ground with specific intent.

Grimoires/Books of Magic: Texts attributed to figures like Faust, containing instructions for conjuration and pacts, although the book focuses on the historical belief in such works rather than their contents.
Ordeal Tools: Objects used in trials, such as the scales for 'weighing a witch' against a church Bible, and the 'water' for the swimming test.
rituals: Witchcraft Pact: Historical accounts describe rituals for formalizing a pact with the Devil, often involving a renunciation of Christian faith, an offering of blood, and a vow of service in exchange for power or familiar spirits. These pacts could be oral or written, sometimes 'sealed with blood.'

Sabbat Meetings: Alleged rituals at the Sabbat involved adoration of Satan (who appeared in various forms like a black man or he-goat), circular dances (often back-to-back), banquets with 'unsalted' foods (and sometimes alleged human flesh), reporting of maleficium to the Devil, and planning future harms.

Sympathetic Magic: The creation and manipulation of wax or clay effigies (poppets) was believed to be a ritualistic method to cause illness, pain, or death. Operations included roasting, pricking with pins or thorns, and burning the effigy to harm the target.

Conjuration of Spirits: Methods for invoking devils or familiar spirits are mentioned, though not detailed as instructions. These were used to find lost items, foresee the future, or direct malevolent spirits to attack individuals or property.

Maleficium: Various harmful rituals were attributed to witches, including causing sickness, death (e.g., through 'evil eye' or curses), destruction of crops ('raise haile, tempests'), making cattle ill, and creating poltergeist-like disturbances in homes.

'When they are to rescue and succour the seruants of God, they can straight waie from the high heauens, which are thousands of thousands of miles distant from the earth, bee present with them. Such quicknesse is also in the diuels ; for their nature being spirituall, and not loden with any heauie matter as our bodies are, doth afford unto them such a nimblenes as we cannot conceiue. By this, they flie through the world over sea and land, and espie out al aduantages and occasions to doe euill.'

'Here take this unbaptized brat : Boile it well ; preserve the fat ; You know 'tis pretious to transfer Our 'noynted flesh into the ayre, In moonelyght nights, on steeple topps, Mountains, and pine trees, that like pricks or stopps, Seeme to our height, high towres, and roofes of princes Like wrinckles in the earth.'
'I shoot yon man in the Divellis name, He sail not win heall hame ! And this sal be alswa trw ; Thair sail not be an bit of him on lieiw.'

'The place where the Diuell suckt my bloud was chosen by himselfe, and in that place, by continuall drawing, there is a thing in the forme of a Teate, at which the Diuell would sucke mee. And I asked the Diuell why he should sucke my bloud, and he sayd, it was to nourish him.'

critical_analysis.relevance: This book serves as an invaluable historical document for scholars of Western Esotericism and Occultism. It compiles a vast array of primary source material on historical demonology and witchcraft beliefs, including trial records, ballads, and treatises. Its relevance lies in illustrating the societal understanding, legal frameworks, and perceived operative mechanics of magic from the late medieval period through the 19th century in Britain and America. It contextualizes the development of these beliefs, showing the transition from a fervent acceptance of physical demonic intervention to more skeptical, yet still folk-rooted, interpretations. The book's strength is its exhaustive collection of accounts, which allows for a deep technical analysis of how occult concepts were articulated and applied in socio-legal contexts.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience for this book would be academic researchers and practitioners in Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magical Studies, particularly those interested in historical demonology, witchcraft trials, and the anthropology of magic. It is also highly relevant for historians of religion, law, and social history, as well as folklorists and cultural studies scholars investigating public perceptions of the supernatural during these periods. While not a practical manual for modern operative magic, it provides critical contextual background for understanding the historical lineages and accusations that shaped many modern esoteric traditions.
